Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Climate Change and Predatory Invasion of the Antarctic Benthos
Award.AbstractNarration: Elevated temperatures and ocean acidification are both threatening the Southern Ocean. The effects of these environmental changes are poorly understood, but preliminary data suggest that they are driving a biological invasion. Specifically, large populations of skeleton-crushing king crabs, Paralomis birsteini, have been detected off Marguerite Bay on the West Antarctic Peninsula. These crabs appear to be invading the continental shelf region where benthic communities have evolved in the absence of such top-predators. Thus, this invasion could result in a wholesale restructuring of the Antarctic benthic ecosystem. The proposed work seeks to document this invasion and better understand the effects of the introduction of P. birsteini on the ecology of this region. A towed underwater vehicle will be used to photographically image communities, and communities with and without P. birsteini will be compared quantitatively. Additionally, crabs will trapped and various aspects of their morphology and physiology will be assessed. This research is unique in that it will document a biological invasion in real-time and it will therefore enhance our general understandings of the drivers of invasion and resilience in biological communities. Results will be widely disseminated through publications as well as through presentations at national and international meetings. In addition, raw data will be made available through open-access databases. This project will support the research and training of undergraduate and graduate students and will foster an international collaboration with British scientists. Researchers on this project will participate in outreach thorough the development of K-12 curricular materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Climate change is altering Antarctic marine ecosystems through rising ocean temperatures and ocean acidification. Seafloor communities in Antarctica face an additional threat: biological invasions driven by a warming climate. Large populations of a shell-crushing king crab, Paralomis birsteini, were discovered in 1998 on the continental slope at Marguerite Bay, off the western Antarctic Peninsula (WAP). As temperatures warm in the upper ocean off the WAP over the next several decades, these predators will likely expand upward and shoreward into coastal waters. Viable populations of king crabs on the continental shelf could spell disaster for the local fauna, because the crabs are potent predators with a generalized diet. The ecological impacts of king crabs on the Antarctic slope are poorly understood. Our goal was to assess the status of Paralomis populations on the slope off the WAP and their potential to disrupt seafloor communities on the shelf.

 Contemporary seafloor communities on the Antarctic shelf lack the shell-crushing predators that structure shallow-seafloor communities elsewhere in the world. A long-term trend of climatic cooling, beginning 41 million years ago in the Eocene epoch, eventually eliminated shell-crushing fish and crustaceans from the Antarctic shelf. In the absence of fish and crustaceans, the seafloor communities have regressed to an ancient, Paleozoic type of community structure, dominated by filter-feeders and with slow-moving seastars and worms as the top predators. Rapidly rising sea temperatures along the WAP are now removing the thermal barrier to survival for those faster-moving, shell-crushing predators. The return of king crabs to the Antarctic shelf could re-modernize the seafloor fauna, making it similar to marine bottom-faunas elsewhere.

The potential for such an invasion was assessed at study sites off Marguerite Bay and Anvers Island, WAP, using three approaches: (1) high-resolution, digital photography of the seafloor; (2) trapping the crabs to determine their health and diet; and (3) long-term measurements of seafloor temperatures on the continental shelf to determine if in fact it is warm enough for the crabs.

In the first approach, a towed vehicle was used to photograph the bottom along transects arranged in a stratified-random design, providing estimates of the population density of Paralomis and other large invertebrates on the continental shelf and slope. Using the images, marine invertebrates were compared between areas of denser and sparser crab populations at the same depths.

 High densities of Paralomis were living on the continental slope but no populations that had yet arrived on the shelf.  Analysis of the images revealed a strongly negative relationship between brittlestar and king-crab population densities, suggesting that king crabs are impacting their invertebrate prey on the slope. The implication is that if the king crabs do expand to the continental shelf, they could have a devastating effect on populations of invertebrates living in shelf habitats.

 Fifty-one crabs were trapped off Marguerite Bay. Data on gender, body dimensions, molting, numbers of eggs, parasite load, gut contents, and sublethal injury (limb loss) were collected for each crab. The information was compared with available data for king-crab stocks at lower, warmer latitudes. Our data revealed robust, reproductively viable populations of king crabs on the slope. We captured males and females, females carrying eggs, and both juveniles and adults. The parasite load of Paralomis was typical of king crabs elsewhere, there was little evidence of sublethal injury, and the gut contents indicated a generalized diet favoring echinoderms and mollusks.  

In the third approach, temperature loggers were deployed on the continental shelf at 450 m depth for 12 months, from February 2015 to February 2016. The loggers recorded seafloor temperatures every 30 minutes. The data provided a measure of the variability in seafloor temperatures that the crabs would be exposed to should they expand onto the shelf.  The temperature data confirmed that there is no longer a cold-temperature barrier to crabs moving up the slope and onto the shelf.   

 This research explored the effects of climate change on the Antarctic marine environment, a subject of deep concern to the scientific community and the public. The study promoted cooperative scientific work between teams from the U.S. and the U.K., and it provided opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral training. It included a research component for students from groups underrepresented in the marine sciences and promoted the advancement of women in scientific careers. The results were used to generate curricular materials for K?12 education. The Principal Investigators gave more than fifty invited presentations related to this research project to general audiences. The findings are providing important information to managers and policymakers by generating data on how climate change is accelerating marine invasions. Such data which are urgently needed to track long-term ecological change in Antarctica.
